questions.text: A patient presenting with high-grade fever and altered sensorium was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime is the drug of choice for empirical treatment of Meningococcal meningitis but Penicillin G remains the antibiotic of choice for Meningococcal meningitis caused by susceptible strains.

  • Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated in patients with suspected bacterial meningitis before the results of CSF Gram stain and culture are known.
  • Pneumoniae and N. meningitidis are the most common etiologic organisms of community-acquired bacterial meningitis.
  • Due to the emergence of penicillin- and cephalosporin-resistant S. pneumoniae, empirical therapy of community-acquired suspected bacterial meningitis in children and adults should include a combination of dexamethasone, a third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or cefepime), and vancomycin, plus acyclovir, as HSV encephalitis is the leading disease in the differential diagnosis, and doxycycline during tick season to treat tick-borne bacterial infections.

questions.text: The drug of choice for treatment of thyrotoxicosis during 1st trimester of pregnancy is______
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for treatment of thyrotoxicosis during 1st trimester of pregnancy is propylthiouracil.

Hyperthyroidism in pregnancy:

Pre-pregnancy and first trimester: Propylthiouracil 

2nd, 3rd trimester + post-pregnancy:

  • Methimazole
  • Partial thyroidectomy (in 2nd trimester if methimazole is not effective)

Methimazole and its prodrug (carbimazole) are usually avoided in the first trimester due to teratogenic risk. However, methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for PTU-associated liver failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for cyanide toxicity?
questions.solution:
Hydroxocobalamin and sodium thiosulfate are the preferred antidotes in cyanide toxicity.

  • If hydroxocobalamin is available,  give hydroxocobalamin and sodium thiosulfate. 
  • If hydroxocobalamin is not available, give amyl nitrite and sodium nitrite and sodium thiosulfate. Avoid nitrites if the patient has contraindications to nitrites.

Hydroxocobalamin is preferred over sodium nitrite as it does not interfere with the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. Also, sodium nitrite can induce fatal methemoglobinemia in patients who are critically ill from another cause.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used as an antagonist in opioid poisoning?
questions.solution:
Naloxone drug is used as an antagonist in opioid poisoning.

Naloxone is a competitive pure opioid antagonist which reverses all effects of an opioid overdose except sedation. It is a pan antagonist with an affinity for all known opioid receptors. It stimulates the release of prolactin in women.

Opioid-induced respiratory depression is mediated by the action of µ receptors (µ2) in the brainstem respiratory centres. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist, which can reverse the respiratory depression induced by opioids.

Opioid Overdose:

Symptoms:

  • Triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils(miosis)
  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia
  • Shallow breathing
  • Hypothermia

Characteristics of opioid toxicity:

  • Opioid intoxication toxidrome - respiratory and mental status depression, analgesia, miosis, orthostatic hypotension, nausea and vomiting, histamine release resulting in localized urticaria and bronchospasm, ileus secondary to decreased GI motility, and urinary retention secondary to increased vesical sphincter tone.
  • Miosis is not universally present from intoxication with every opioid; normal or even enlarged pupils have been documented secondary to diphenoxylate, meperidine, morphine, pentazocine, and propoxyphene toxicity.
  • Opioid-induced acute lung injury, previously known as non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, is an uncommon complication associated with heroin overdose.

Airway protection and ventilatory maintenance are the most important treatment steps for opioid intoxications, because respiratory depression is the major morbidity and the cause of essentially all the mortality.

  • After adequate ventilation is ensured, administer naloxone.
  • Single-dose activated charcoal can be administered in case opioid ingestion occured within one hour. 

Opioid withdrawal symptoms (mnemonic- O MY WITHDRAWALS):

  • Mydriasis
  • Yawning
  • Weakness
  • Insomnia, irritability
  • Tremors, tachycardia
  • Hyperthermia, hypertension
  • Diarrhoea
  • Rhinorrhoea
  • Apnoeic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Anxiety
  • Lacrimation
  • Sweating

 

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: A short-acting opioid antagonist with a duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborn due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: A Long-acting opioid antagonist with a with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: A Long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with fever and barking cough for the last 2 days presented to the pediatric emergency at 2.30 am. On examination, respiratory rate is 36/ min, the temperature of 39 °C and stridor heard only on crying. No other abnormality is found. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) of mild severity. The treatment of choice for this child is High-dose dexamethasone.

Laryngotracheobronchitis in a child is characterized by a barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor. Agitation and crying aggravate the symptoms and signs. A hoarse voice, coryza, normal to the moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate can be revealed in the physical examination. The upper airway obstruction may progress and the child can present with an increased respiratory rate, nasal flaring; suprasternal, infrasternal, and intercostal retractions; and continuous stridor.

The severity of croup is determined by the Westley croup score.

Mild croup – Stridor may be present when upset or crying but it is not present at rest. Barking cough, hoarse cry, and either no or only mild chest wall/subcostal retractions are seen.

Moderate croup- Stridor is present at rest. Mild retractions are at least present. Children may have other symptoms or signs of respiratory distress. The child does not appear agitated.

Severe croup – Stridor is present at rest. Retractions are severe that include indrawing of the sternum. The child may appear anxious, and agitated.

Hospitalization is done in a child for any of the following:

  • progressive stridor,
  • severe stridor at rest,
  • respiratory distress,
  • hypoxia,
  • cyanosis,
  • depressed mental status,
  • poor oral intake,

Treatment: Oral corticosteroids are beneficial in mild croup. It decreases the edema in the laryngeal mucosa through its anti-inflammatory action and reduces hospitalization, shorter the duration of hospitalization. It also reduces the need for subsequent interventions such as epinephrine administration.

Nebulized racemic epinephrine is the choice of treatment for moderate or severe croup which is characterized by moderate to severe croup at rest. Antibiotics are not indicated in children who present with croup.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of generalized weakness for 6 months. She has also had frequent headaches, mild fever and severe jaw pain. She does not complain of any vision abnormality.  She appears pale. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ESR. Peripheral smear shows normochromic anemia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient >50 years with fever, weakness, anemia, jaw claudication, and high ESR and CRP levels is suggestive of a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis.
The drug of choice is prednisone.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have temporal artery abnormalities such as enlargement, tenderness, nodular swelling, and loss of pulse of the temporal artery, either unilateral or bilateral. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. 

GCA is very commonly associated with polymyalgia rheumatica characterized by morning stiffness and pain around the shoulders and hip. Mononeuropathies or peripheral neuropathies can also be seen. A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness. Therefore treatment with oral steroids is given first and then a temporal artery biopsy is done for confirming the diagnosis. As the diagnosis may be done clinically, treatment is started immediately rather than delaying it after the biopsy.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is on treatment develops a HBA1c level of 8.1%. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
A hypertensive patient developing diabetes should be switched to telmisartan.

Telmisartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), has shown evidence of having PPAR-gamma agonist action. It is very useful in hypertensive patients with diabetes. PPAR-gamma agonists are the thiazolidinedione group of drugs that act by inducing several insulins sensitizing genes, thereby reducing overall insulin resistance.

ACE inhibitors or ARBs are the first-line treatment of choice for hypertension in a diabetic patient. They reduce proteinuria and delay diabetic nephropathy, a benefit that is not seen with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery?
questions.solution:
First- and second-generation cephalosporins (cefazolin) are the drugs of choice for preoperative prophylaxis for cardiac surgery. Clindamycin is reserved for cases of allergy to beta-lactams and vancomycin is recommended for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

Preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis is essential in reducing the risk of surgical site infections, particularly in cardiac surgery, where the consequences of infection can be severe. The choice of antibiotic depends on the patient's medical history, allergies, and the most common pathogens involved in surgical site infections for the specific surgery. In addition to cefazolin, other cephalosporins, such as cefuroxime, can also be used for prophylaxis in cardiac surgery. The timing of antibiotic administration is crucial, with the first dose typically given within 60 minutes before the incision.

Other Options:

Option A: Penicillin G is not the drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in cardiac surgery. It is mainly used to treat infections caused by susceptible gram-positive bacteria, such as Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and some strains of Staphylococcus aureus.

Option B: Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic and is not the drug of choice for preoperative prophylaxis in cardiac surgery. It is typically used to treat respiratory tract infections, skin infections, and other infections caused by susceptible gram-positive bacteria.

Option C: Azithromycin, another macrolide antibiotic, is also not the drug of choice for preoperative prophylaxis in cardiac surgery. It is commonly used to treat respiratory tract infections, sexually transmitted infections, and other infections caused by susceptible gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes with severe headache and difficulty in moving his right hand and leg. CT Angiogram showed a ruptured aneurysm in the Circle of Willis area. Which of the following drug is indicated to prevent neurological sequelae for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The drug indicated to prevent neurological sequelae for this patient is nimodipine.

It is a short-acting Dihyro Pyridine calcium channel blocker that penetrates the blood-brain barrier and has a high affinity for the cerebral blood vessels. It is believed to selectively relax cerebral vasculature and is approved for the prevention and treatment of neurological deficits due to cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage or ruptured congenital intracranial aneurysms.

Nimodipine can significantly improve clinical outcomes, and it can reduce the occurrence of symptomatic cerebral vasospasm and delayed neurological function deficits. It also reduces mortality after subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: A patient presents with photophobia and blurring of vision. On examination, the eye appears as shown below.  What is the mainstay of treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of photophobia and blurring of vision along with red-eye and irregularly shaped pupil (image) suggest a diagnosis of uveitis. Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of the treatment of uveitis.

Steroids are the drug of choice in anterior uveitis. They reduce inflammation by their anti-inflammatory effect. 

Cycloplegics like 1% atropine, relieve spasm of the iris sphincter and ciliary muscles. They prevent the formation of synechiae and reduce exudation.

Systemic therapy includes steroids, NSAIDs, and immunosuppressants. 

Immunosuppressants like voclosporin (calcineurin inhibitor), are used in severe cases. They are being studied under a program called LUMINATE.

questions.text: A highway truck driver has profuse rhinorrhea and sneezing. Which among the following drugs will you prescribe him?
questions.solution:
The truck driver is suffering from allergic rhinitis and fexofenadine can be prescribed to him. This is preferred as it is a second-generation antihistamine having minimal/no sedative effects as it cannot cross the blood-brain barrier easily.

Pheniramine, promethazine, hydroxyzine are first-generation antihistamines which should not be prescribed to drivers and heavy machine workers because they are lipophilic and cross the blood-brain barrier easily and causes sedation. 

Highly sedative first-generation antihistamines:

  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Promethazine
  • Hydroxyzine

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient was posted for unilateral mastectomy for breast carcinoma. Halothane was used as the inhalational agent. Intraoperatively she develops fever and tachycardia. On physical examination, rigidity was noted in the masseter muscle. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. The drug of choice for the condition is dantrolene.

Dantrolene is a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on the RyR1 (ryanodine receptor) calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles and inhibits calcium-induced calcium release. This results in the uncoupling of membrane depolarization and muscle contraction, thus inhibiting muscle contraction.

Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic condition in which mutated RyR1 receptors are present in the skeletal muscles. In the presence of certain triggers, this mutated RyR1 causes severe dysfunction in the RyR1 channels. This leads to the accumulation of calcium ions in the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction, rigidity, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal CO2.

Drugs triggering malignant hyperthermia:

  • Succinylcholine
  • Halothane
  • Isoflurane
  • Sevoflurane

Susceptible patients:

  • Patients with a positive family history. It can be inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.
  • Patients with congenital myopathies.

Treatment: 

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive treatment with rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia should be given

Other options:

Options A and C: Succinylcholine and isoflurane are known to cause malignant hyperthermia, and hence cannot be used for the management.

Option D: Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student comes to the emergency room with a history of palpitations, sweating and a feeling of impending doom for the past 45 minutes while preparing for his exam. He gives a previous history of similar complaints. There is no history of medical illness or substance abuse. Which of the following should be given in the acute management of his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a panic attack. Benzodiazepines such as alprazolam are used to treat panic attacks.

A panic attack is a sudden period of intense fear or apprehen­sion that may last from minutes to hours. Panic attacks can occur in panic disorders, specific phobia, social phobia and post-traumatic stress disorder. They may occur at any time and are not associated with any identifiable stimulus.

Some habits predispose a patient to panic attacks. These include use of caffeine, alcohol, nicotine, or other substances, and unusual patterns of sleeping or eating. 

 The first panic attack is often spontaneous, although panic attacks occasionally follow excitement, physical exertion, sexual activity, or moderate emotional trauma. 

The major symptoms are extreme fear and a sense of impending death and doom. Physi­cal signs often include tachycardia, palpitations, dyspnea or hyperventilation, and sweating. Patients often try to leave whatever situation they are in to seek help. The attack generally lasts 20 to 30 minutes and rarely more than an hour. Hyperventilation can produce respiratory alkalosis and other symptoms.

For rapid control of symptoms, alprazolam is the drug of choice. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as paroxetine are started concurrently and alprazolam is slowly tapered. Fluoxetine is used for panic attacks with co-morbid depression.

questions.text: The drug of choice in the SAFE strategy of trachoma treatment is _______.
questions.solution:
Oral azithromycin is given as part of the SAFE strategy for trachoma management.

  • 1 g for adults
  • 20 mg/kg body weight for children

The drug of choice in trachoma is azithromycin.

A single dose of oral azithromycin is as effective in a as six weeks of daily tetracycline ointment. Because of the difficulty of using the ointment and its unpopularity, a single dose oral drug would be far superior.

 

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

Strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (1–9 yrs)

  • Prevalence >10% → SAFE
  • 5 to 10% → FE
  • < 5% → NO intervention

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia. Which of the following is used to manage the urinary symptoms in the initial stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
Tamsulosin is used for the management of urinary symptoms in the initial stages of Benign prostatic hyperplasia(BPH). It improves the urinary flow by inhibiting the smooth muscle contraction of the prostate thereby reducing the resistance at the bladder neck.

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Conservative treatment is recommended for men with mild symptoms, flow rate >10ml/s, and good bladder emptying with residual urine <100ml. 

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. Tamsulosin is an adrenoreceptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. Finasteride is a 5α-reductase enzyme inhibitor. It is effective in the treatment of palpable enlarged prostate. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Hematuria
  • Stone formation
  • Hydronephrosis, hydroureter with renal functional impairment

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). Laser ablative techniques using holmium YAG can also be done.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant lady at 32 weeks of gestation presents with vaginal discharge associated with itching and burning. On examination, the following finding is seen. Which of the following can be used in the treatment of this patient?

choices.text: Tab. Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the image showing curdy white vaginal discharge is suggestive of monilial vaginitis/vaginal candidiasis. A single dose of fluconazole 150 mg can be used in the treatment of this condition.

Local intravaginal application of antifungal agents such as imidazole, miconazole, clotrimazole, butoconazole or ter­conazole vaginal pessaries or creams used for 3–6 days is also very effective. Since the use of fluconazole has been associated with embryotoxicity and increased risk of cardiac malformations, it is recommended to be avoided during the first trimester.

Risk factors for candidal infection include pregnancy, medications such as oral contraceptive pills, steroids, HIV, and diabetes mellitus. Clinical features include itching, curdy-white discharge, burning, and dysuria with vaginal pH <4.5. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by microscopic examination of the smear of vaginal discharge with 10% KOH solution. The smear shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. Culture can be done on Sabouraud's agar and Nickerson's medium.

Treatment includes control and elimination of risk factors including maintaining personal hygiene, adequate control of diabetes, and stopping contributing medications, in addition to pharmacotherapy as mentioned above. Routine treatment of the partner is not recommended unless the partner is symptomatic.

Other options:

Option A- Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days is used in the treatment of vaginosis/bacterial vaginitis/nonspecific vaginitis.

Option B- Azithromycin 1 g single dose is used in the treatment of chlamydial infections and chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Option D- Metronidazole 2 g single dose is used in the treatment of vaginosis/bacterial vaginitis/nonspecific vaginitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester was found to be positive for plasmodium falciparum malaria. What treatment would she be started on?
questions.solution:

Treatment of vivax malaria during pregnancy:

Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for Kawasaki disease is:
questions.solution:
Treatment of choice in Kawaski disease is IV immunoglobulins. IV immunoglobulins along with aspirin have proven beneficial in preventing coronary artery abnormalities.

Tocilizumab is used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis and rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy with a known diagnosis of sickle cell disease presents with fever and painful swelling of hands and feet. Which of the following is the drug of choice to prevent painful crises in sickle cell anaemia?
questions.solution:
Hydroxyurea is the drug of choice for the prevention of painful crises in sickle cell anaemia.

Hydroxyurea is a myelosuppressive agent that is effective in reducing the frequency of painful episodes, decreasing the rate of hospitalization and requirement for blood transfusion. It is safe and well-tolerated in children and infants.

Other options:

  • Hydrocodone is used in the treatment of pain crisis in sickle cell anaemia.
  • Corticosteroids is one of the first-line therapies for acute idiopathic thrombocytic purpura (ITP) with risk factors for bleeding.
  • Ruxolitinib is the drug of choice for treatment of polycythemia vera.

questions.text: A newborn infant developed respiratory distress 2 days after birth. On examination, she is mottled and has weak upper extremity pulses and absent femoral pulses. Investigations revealed coarctation of the aorta. Which of the following drugs can be used to keep the ductus open medically before surgical repair?
questions.solution:
Alprostadil, a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analogue, can be used to keep the ductus open medically in the coarctation of aorta.

Survival of newborns with certain heart lesions such as coarctation of the aorta, hypoplastic left heart syndrome and transposition of great vessels depends on the ductus arteriosus patency (ductal-dependant lesions). Closure of PDA in such conditions can lead to hypoperfusion, severe hypoxia and cyanosis.

PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of ductal smooth muscle. PGE1 analogues like alprostadil, misoprostol and rioprostil can keep the ductus open and support systemic blood supply.

Ibuprofen and indomethacin are used in patent ductus arteriosus to close the ductus medically.

Mifepristone, also known as RU-486, is used in combination with misoprostol to bring about abortion during pregnancy and manage early miscarriage.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for prophylaxis of chronic cluster headaches?
questions.solution:
The drugs used in the prophylaxis of chronic cluster headaches are:

  • Verapamil - drug of choice
  • Prednisone
  • Lithium
  • Topiramate
  • Gabapentin
  • Melatonin
  • Greater occipital nerve injection with lidocaine and glucocorticoids

Cluster headache is a periodic headache characterized by daily attacks of short-duration unilateral headache lasting 8-10 weeks a year. It presents as severe, unilateral retro-orbital pain with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection. The pain, though severe, is characteristically brief (15-180 minutes). Patients are usually perfectly well in between episodes.

The most suitable treatment is pharmacologic prevention of future bouts of headaches. An acute episode can be treated with 

  • Sumatriptan 6 mg subcutaneous injection
  • 100% O2 at 10 -12 L/min for 15 - 20 mins
  • Sumatriptan (20 mg) and zolmitriptan (5 mg) nasal spray.
  • Noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation (nVNS) is also approved by the FDA for the treatment of acute episodes of cluster headaches.

Other options:

Oral sumatriptan is not effective for the treatment or prevention of acute cluster headaches. The nasal spray form of sumatriptan is used in the management of acute attacks. Gabapentin is not the drug of choice, though it has a role in prophylaxis of cluster headaches.

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presents with episodes of a sudden sensation of intense heat involving the face and upper chest which rapidly spreads across the entire body. The episodes last about 2-4 minutes and are associated with profuse sweating, palpitations, and anxiety. What is the most effective treatment for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes) in a postmenopausal woman. Estrogen therapy is found to be the most effective to treat it.

Hot flushes are episodes of vasodilation affecting the face and the neck. The episode lasts for 2–5 min each. These are followed by severe sweating, palpitations, anxiety, and anginal pains may be felt. Multiple episodes occur during the day, but are more severe at night and can disturb sleep. Sometimes they can be preceded by headaches.

Hormone therapy in postmenopausal women is only indicated for the treatment of:

  • vasomotor symptoms
  • osteoporosis (prevention and treatment)
  • vaginal atrophy
  • urethral syndrome
  • dyspareunia

Estrogen can be given as oral estrogen formulations, transdermal patches, topical gel, or intravaginal formulations. For Dyspareunia, urethral syndrome, and senile vaginitis local estrogen cream is preferred over oral therapy. Short-term therapy is recommended for vasomotor symptoms whereas osteoporosis requires long-term therapy. Estrogen should be given in the smallest effective dose for the shortest duration possible. 

 Other treatments: 

Hormonal Non-Hormonal Non-prescriptive

Estrogen therapy (Most effective)

Progestin

Combination preparations

Tibolone

Clonidine 

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (like Fluoxetine)

selective norepinephrine- reuptake inhibitor(like desvenlafaxine)

Gabapentin

Vitamin E

Soya 

Isoflavones

Contraindications of HRT:

  • Undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
  • Known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasia
  • Active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • Active or recent (e.g., within the past year) arterial thromboembolic disease
  • Liver dysfunction or gall bladder disease
  • Known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the estrogen preparation
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine fibroids as these may enlarge in size.

For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur after 6 months of estrogen therapy. For women without uterus just estrogen therapy is sufficient.

questions.text: A patient presented with scaly lesions as shown in the image below. He later developed arthritis and nail changes.  What is the treatment of choice for this?
questions.solution:
The patient has right knee effusion, dactylitis of multiple digits, and sharply demarcated scaly red papulosquamous lesions on both knees all of which point toward a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. 

Methotrexate and apremilast are the first-line drugs for the treatment of moderate to severe psoriasis associated with psoriatic arthritis.

Features of psoriatic arthritis are :

  • Asymmetrical oligoarthritis
  • associated with nail pitting/ onycholysis, or
  • dactylitis, enthesitis 
  • Inflammation is prominent in the distal interphalangeal joints 
  • There is dactylitis with pronounced telescoping.
  • Nail dystrophy (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis) affects each of the fingers
  • Axial involvement may occur

Radiological features:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of DIP joint
  • marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation "whiskering"
  • small joint ankylosis
  • Ray distribution of lesions

Indications for methotrexate (inflammatory conditions) include:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Psoriasis 
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Polymyositis
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Giant cell arteritis 
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Other systemic vasculitis
  • Graft versus host disease associated with organ transplantation.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics have a role in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
Rifaximin is used in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy. It lowers the blood ammonia levels by reducing ammonia production in the gut by eliminating ammonia-producing bacteria in the gut.

Treatment of hepatic encephalopathy includes:

  • Correction of precipitating factors
  • Lactulose - decreases the absorption of ammonia in the gut by converting NH3 into NH4+
  • Rifaximin - lowers the blood ammonia levels
  • L-ornithine L-aspartate

questions.text: A child presents with continuing seizures for the past 30 minutes. The relatives say that there had been no seizure-free intervals in the past 30 minutes. After stabilizing the vitals of the patient, the first drug the patient should be started on is:
questions.solution:
This scenario described above is of status epilepticus. The first line drug used is Diazepam/Lorazepam.

Status epilepticus refers to continuous or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness which lasts for more than 5 minutes.

The duration of seizure activity to meet the definition of status epilepticus has traditionally been specified as 15–30 min. However, a more practical definition is to consider status epilepticus as a situation in which the duration of seizures prompts the acute use of anticonvulsant therapy, i.e., more than 5 minutes.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she developed dialysis disequilibrium syndrome. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The treatment for this patients with dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS) or the reverse urea effect is IV mannitol 

It is an acute complication that occurs especially in patients undergoing dialysis for the first time.

During dialysis, urea in blood vessels is rapidly removed as compared to that in the interstitium. This decreases the osmolality of blood. This results in a fluid shift from the blood vessels into the interstitium and brain parenchyma, causing cerebral edema.

DDS can present as headache, nausea, blurred vision, restlessness, confusion, and severe manifestations like coma and seizures in rare cases.

The most common risk factors include

  • First hemodialysis treatment
  • High blood urea nitrogen (BUN) (above 175 mg/dL or 60 mmol/L) before initiation of dialysis
  • Children and elderly
  • Sudden change in dialysis regimen
  • Hyponatremia, hepatic encephalopathy
  • Sepsis, meningitis, encephalitis, hemolytic uremic syndrome, vasculitis
  • History of stroke, malignant hypertension, head trauma, or seizure disorder

Management includes changing the sodium dialysate bath or engaging the changed prescription on the dialysis machine. Intravenous mannitol can be used to reduce intracerebral pressure in severe symptoms of DDS.

DDS can be prevented by 

  • Slow and gentle initial hemodialysis
  • Limiting the clearance of urea to prevent the development of an osmotic gradient
  • Administration of osmotically active substance

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for drug induced Parkinson’s disease?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for drug-induced Parkinson’s disease is benzhexol.

Benzhexol is an antimuscarinic agent. Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition that is caused by certain drugs that have D2 antagonistic action like typical antipsychotics. Due to the decrease in dopaminergic activity, they result in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Benzhexol is a centrally-acting antimuscarinic agent. It acts by restoring the cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons. 

The following drugs are implicated in drug-induced parkinsonism:

Drug class

Examples 
Typical antipsychotics

Phenothiazines, haloperidol
Atypical antipsychotics Risperidone, olanzapine
Dopamine depleters Reserpine, tetrabenazine
Antiemetics Metoclopramide, levosulpiride

questions.text: A 55-year old man presents with an inability to hold his head up, progressive atrophy and weakness of his hands and forearms over the past few months. On examination, he is found to have spasticity of the legs and brisk jaw jerk. What is the drug that can be given to improve his survival and slow down the progression of this disease?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with both upper motor and lower motor lesions is suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Riluzole is the drug that can be given to improve his survival and slow down the progression of this disease.

Riluzole is absorbed orally and is highly protein-bound. It works by reducing excitotoxicity by blocking voltage-dependent sodium channels and by diminishing glutamate release. Riluzole extended the survival of ALS patients by 2-3 months.

questions.text: A known alcoholic patient is brought to the emergency in a disoriented state. He complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin. Which of the following should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards delirium tremens likely due to acute alcohol withdrawal. Lorazepam + thiamine should be given to this patient.

Delirium tremens occurs after 2-4 days of abstinence in a heavy or chronic drinker. It is characterized by autonomic hyperactivity, tremors, delusions, and hallucinations. It usually resolves spontaneously in 7 days but may cause the death of the patient due to cardiovascular collapse or infections or self-injury.

Delirium tremens is treated using benzodiazepines starting with a higher dosage which is gradually tapered as withdrawal symptoms disappear. In cases of chronic alcohol use, vitamin deficiency (especially thiamine) may be co-existing and hence bolus doses of thiamine are given to prevent/treat Wernicke encephalopathy.

Haloperidol is generally not the first-line drug in case of alcoholic withdrawal. It might be used as an add-on in agitated patients. It decreases the seizure threshold and its use would be appropriate in a case of co-existing psychotic disorder like schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with hepatitis and personality changes. A picture of her eye has been provided below. Which of the following is the drug of choice for pregnant women and maintenance therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image provided above represents the Kayser-Fleischer ring which is seen in Wilson's disease. The drug of choice for maintenance therapy in this condition is Zinc.

Wilsons disease is an autosomal-recessive disease caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea. It is characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomic. It does not interfere with vision. It is present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms. However, the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Neurological: Dystonia, rigidity, tremor or choreiform movements, abnormal gait due to basal ganglia (e.g., caudate, putamen) involvement.
  • Behavioural disturbancesOccular characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Diagnosis:

    • Sternlieb's criteria: Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

The initial treatment in symptomatic patients is the administration of copper-chelating agents, which leads to the rapid excretion of excess deposited copper.

  • D-penicillamine: It increases urinary excretion of copper and prevents copper overload. Pyridoxine (vitamin B6 ) is administered along with it to counter pyridoxine deficiency that occurs due to penicillamine.
  • Triethylenetetramine dihydrochloride: This chelating agent is given in patients intolerant to D-penicillamine and those with severe neurologic manifestations (D-penicillamine worsens neurological status).
  • Zinc acetate: This is used due to its unique ability to impair the gastrointestinal absorption of copper. Zinc is beneficial in pregnancy (lower teratogenic effects) and as a maintenance therapy.
  • Liver transplantation: This is considered in advanced stages of irreversible hepatic damage or poor compliance to medical therapy.
